text: Don't worry if something doesn't work. If everything worked, you would be fired.
author: Mosherâ€™s Law of Software Engineering

text: In good design, adding something costs less than the thing itself.
author: Thomas C. Gale

text: In theory, theory and practice are inseparable. In practice, this is not the case.
author: Yoggi Berra

text: Measuring a programmer's productivity by counting lines of code is like judging an airplane's build by its weight.
author: Bill Gates

text: Debugging code is twice as hard as writing it. So if you write code as smart as you can, then by definition you are not smart enough to debug it.
author: Brian W Kernighan

text: Many of you are familiar with the virtues of being a programmer. There are only three of them, and of course this is: laziness, impatience and pride.
author: Larry Wall

text: Always write code as if it would be accompanied by a violent psychopath who knows where you live.
author: Martin Golding

text: If you give a person a program, you will keep him busy for one day. If you teach a person to program, you will keep him busy for life.
author: Waseem Latif

text: Debugging code is like hunting. Hunting for bugs.
author: Amit Kalantri

text: Programming is about breaking something big and impossible into something small and quite real.
author: Jazzwant

text: Simplicity is the key to reliability.
author: Edsger W. Dijkstra

text: Does it work? Do not touch.
author: Any programmer

text: The difficulty of working with a programmer is that you cannot understand what he is doing until it is too late.
author: Seymour Cray

text: I think this will be a new feature. Just don't tell anyone that it happened by accident.
author: Larry Wall

text: Magic ceases to exist after you understand how it works.
author: Tim Berners-Lee

text: Laziness is the natural state of a programmer, after which he gives birth to a good algorithm.
author: Folk art

text: Some problems are better not solved, but avoided.
author: Tony Hoare

text: You can't trust code that you haven't written completely yourself.
author: Ken Thompson
